projects.title: Docker Monitor with ESP8266
projects.description: A physical dashboard that monitors server status in real-time via an OLED screen, web panel, and a custom-developed REST API.
projects.details:
I built this project to get an overview of my home server's containers without having to log in via SSH. 

The system consists of two main components: 

1. A Backend (Python/Flask) that communicates with the Docker Socket to retrieve the status of all containers, sorts containers with errors to the top, and exposes the data via a JSON API.

2. An ESP8266 + screen that fetches and visualizes the data and also functions as a web server. 

One of the biggest technical challenges was the limited RAM on the ESP8266. To prevent crashes when handling large JSON objects and graphics simultaneously, I implemented 'Page Buffer' rendering via the U8g2 library and dynamic memory allocation. It changes pages automatically, but you can also click the flash button to scroll between the pages yourself. 

I also implemented better sorting of containers so that down-containers are displayed first, as well as an automatic night mode that dims the screen based on NTP time synchronization. 
I also made a web panel that runs directly on the ESP to easily see the same thing via a web browser.

projects.title: Pokémon battle simulator
projects.description: A CLI-based program that simulates the classic Pokémon battle from Pokémon Red/Blue/Yellow, where the user can watch the battle unfold in the terminal.
projects.details:
I built this project as a fun exercise in Python, where I wanted to recreate the classic Pokémon battle in a text-based form. 

The program selects three random Pokémon for both the player and the opponent, and then the battle is simulated in the terminal with color-coded output to show damage, status changes, and type advantages. 

I used the Colorama library to make the output more visually appealing, and Just_Playback to add sound and music support during the battle.

projects.title: Trivia Game in Python
projects.description: A simple trivia game in Python made with customTkinter where the user can test their knowledge in different categories and difficulty levels.
projects.details:
I built this project as an exercise in Python and GUI development with customTkinter. The game offers multiple categories (e.g., History, Technology, Music) and three difficulty levels (Easy, Medium, Hard). 

The user can answer or pass on questions, and the score is tracked during the game, the user can then see their final score when the game is over. 

I used customTkinter to create a more modern and visually appealing GUI compared to standard Tkinter. 

This is an old project (~2021) but I still think it's worth showing off :)

projects.title: TypoTwist
projects.description: A website for typography nerds where users can enter text and see it rendered in different fonts and styles. Simple but elegant.
projects.details:
Built with the usual tech stack for the easiest deployment on GitHub Pages. 

The website shows how text can be rendered in different fonts and styles using the Google Fonts API. 

The user can enter text and see it rendered in real-time in different fonts, making it a fun tool for exploring typography and finding the perfect font for different purposes.
